publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 87.3

milestone.n: Book 13 (Satkāravarga), part 1, strophe 56(?), and part 2, strophes 1-9.

seg.seg: ... the arrow piercing the heart ... avoid, you monks [56d?].

|| In Dharmasoma's Udānālaṅkāra the first part of the Satkāravarga. || In [the metre] Subhādra: || The jewel of the teaching, the Udāna, the monk's sign ["book of teaching"] [is] called the satiation of the good
Who dismisses all attachment, leaves all things behind him, severs all fetters, who has cleansed the mind of all things, he indeed can clearly understand the taste of monkhood. [1d]
Who lets go all clinging, gives up all things, cuts off all bonds, [his] mind turned away from all things, he can indeed clearly recognise the taste of monkhood. (cf : ii, 54)
Wer alle Haftungen löst, alle Dinge hinter sich lässt, alle Fesseln zerschneidet, [wer] den Geist von allen Dingen abgewendet(?) [hat], kann in der Tat den Geschmack des Mönchtums genau erkennen.
Who[ever] undoes all attachments, leaves all things behind him, severs all bonds, [whoever has] turned the mind away(?) from all things, [he] indeed can perceive clearly the taste of monkhood.

The deed takes the possessions away from some, thieves rob them from others, too. The lord, the lover takes this away, the army will make that into odour, the fire burns it, [and] the water carries it [away].
The lord, [or] the beloved takes this, the army may reduce [lit. make] that to a scent, [or] fire burns it, [or] water carries it off.
Die Tat nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses [rest of translation missing in [[Schmidt 1974]].]
The deed takes away the possessions from some; thieves rob it from others. The lord, the lover takes this [rest of translation missing in Schmidt 1974.]
Das Karman nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie auch den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen.
The deed takes the possessions of some, thieves rob them off others. The lord, the lover takes this, the army will make that a [mere] smell.
Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen.
The lord, the lover takes this, the army will turn that into a [mere] smell.

If one gives up possession and property by himself, by faith and world-weariness, he will not be able to gather a second time either. [2d] The householder must care for a lot of things, for slaves and female slaves, for [his] wife
If someone himself gives up [his] property [and] possessions out of faith [and] weariness of the world, he will not gather [possessions] for a second time. (cf : ii, 54–55)
Wenn einer [von] selbst Besitz [und] Vermögen aufgibt im Glauben [und] Weltüberdruss, wird er [sie] auch nicht zum zweitenmal sammeln.
If someone gives up possession[s] [and] wealth [of] his own [account], in faith [and] world-weariness, he will not gather [them] a second time.

for sons and daughters, for the service to the king, for the land’s levy, and for [his] own possession he must care, therefore they desire possession. But if he who has gone from the house and who is eating alms that he obtained by begging, [if he] is gathering possessions,
But if he who has left the house, eating begging [alms], gathers possessions, he is besmirched with great blame. (cf : ii, 55)
Wenn aber der, welcher aus dem Hause gegangen und Bettelbrot essend ist, Besitztümer sammelt, wird er mit großem Makel beworfen.
If, however, he who has gone from the house and is eating food he has begged for gathers possessions, he will be pelted by great fault.

with great blemish he is besmirched. [3d] Had you cared for veneration and flattery, you should have stayed in the house yourselves [in the first place]. By your respective male and female slaves you certainly would have obtained veneration

If you [pl.] had been concerned about reverence and flattery, [and] you [pl.] had yourselves further stayed in your [own] hous[es], then each of you would certainly have obtained reverence from his male and female slaves, [and] gathered possessions. (: ii, 55, slightly different)

[and] gathered possessions. Now you have gone from the house, by the wish for deliverance, [but] you let are bound [by] the fetters of veneration, flattery and profit. [4d] As if he was a miserable dog, [who is infected with] worms – [and] they eat by day
Ihr seid jetzt in dem Wunsche nach Erlösung aus dem Hause gegangen, [aber dennoch] lasst ihr euch (durch) die Bande des Verlangens nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei binden.
Wishing for release, you have now gone from the house, [but still] you let yourselves be bound (by) the bond of desire for reverence [and] flattery.

[Just] as when a miserable dog is wormy, [then] worms eat from his wounds by day and by night, so when the worms of profit are born in the wound of insatiability, they eat his dharma body by day and by night [and] he gets no rest. (cf : ii, 55)

Wie wenn er ein elender Hund wäre, welcher Würmer hat - es fressen ihm bei Tag [und] Nacht die Würmer [an den] Wunden -, so fressen ihm die Würmer des Gewinns, wenn sie in der Wunde der Unersättlichkeit entstehen, [an] seinem Rechtskörper bei Tag [und] Nacht, er findet keine Ruhe.

As if he was a miserable dog that has [been infected with] maggots - the maggots eat away [at his] wounds by day [and] by night -, thus the maggots of profit, when they appear in the wound of insatiability, eat away [at] his body of law by day [and] by night, he finds no peace.
[and] night away at his wounds these worms – thus the worms of profit, when they are born into the wound of insatiability, eat [away] at his body of law by day [and] by night, he gets no [peace].

With shining eyes he looks: wherefrom could I get possession? [5d] The discipline of monks he leads from house to house, he dismisses the study of the twelve kinds, he rejects meditation, he keeps away
Die mönchische Zurückhaltung führt er Haus für Haus, gibt das Studium in den zwölf Arten auf, weist die Versenkung zurück, hält das Wissen fern; [nur] nach Ehre [und] Schmeichelei verlangt er.
Monkish reserve he leads from house to house, he gives up the study in the twelve ways, rejects meditation, keeps knowledge away; [only] reverence [and] flattery he desires.

knowledge; [only] veneration and flattery he desires. With the six ulterior motives he continually begs, street by street, house by house: this one and that one should flatter me. [6d] Only for me the kings should be,

only for me the ministers, only for me all [people] of this country. Householders and those having gone from the house should always make veneration only to me, not before anyone else should they bow to the ground. If he sees or hears
Haushalter [und] aus dem Hause Gegangene sollten nur mir stets Verehrung machen, nicht vor einem anderen sollten sie sich zur Erde neigen.
Householders [and those who] have gone from the house at all times should make veneration only to me, before no other they should bow to the ground.
If he sees or hears the honour of somebody else, he is burnt by the fire of jealousy: «this should be put together with that!» (cf : ii, 55)
Wenn er von der Verehrung eines anderen sieht oder hört, wird er vom Feuer der Eifersucht verzehrt [wtl. verbrannt] [in dem Gedanken]: ""Der müsste sich mit diesem und jenem zusammen hinstellen."
If he sees or hears of reverence [paid] to another he is consumed [lit. burned] by the fire of jealousy [thinking]: "This one should be standing with this one and that one."

about the veneration of another, he burns in the fire of discord [thinking]: he should be standing there together with this one and that one. [7d] The Buddha spoke many Sūtras and about veneration and flattery countless words of cen-

-sure. This somehow I will show you here in brevity: [it is] a saying by the one having the ten powers: “You in whom arose an tendency for veneration and flattery, let [your] thoughts turn away [from it] as from this excrement
Ihr, denen hier die Neigung nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei entstanden [ist], lasset eure Gedanken sich [davon] abkehren wie von einer Kotgrube!
You, [in] whom [has] developed an inclination to reverence [and] flattery, let your thoughts turn away [from it] as if from a cesspit!

sewer.” [8d] “Just as the flood(?) here destroys the seeds, rips off the flowers [and] kills the fruits, so does veneration and flattery here destroy the seeds of moral conduct [and] also the flowers of enlightenment [and] the monk-
-hood's fruit (it kills).” “Of veneration and flattery ... [9d] ... (as) if it enters the forest, a (?)

p.note: Includes remainders of the last strophe (56?) of the first part of the Satkāravarga (XIII) in a 21/21/18/13-syllable-metre and the beginning of the second part, strophes 1-9 in a 20/22/10/15-syllable-metre (rhythm: a: 5/5/5/5, b: 8/7/7, c: 5/5, d: 8/7).
Almost complete leaf, like damaged at the top edge.
According to 69 fn. 8 the reading eṅkalñanta should be corrected to eṅkalñenta and according to 69 fn. 9 kerketse should be corrected to kerketseṃ in the transcription.
The ‹pa› of kraupalle was added a posteriori to the manuscript according to 70 fn. 1.
According to 70 fn. 1 mā ṣpä should be read as mā ṣp and according to 70 fn. 2 the reading māñye should be correctet to māñyeṃ.
According to 70 fn. 5 the reading yṅkau should be corrected to yṅkauṃ.
According to 70 fn. 6 the reading pelaikneṣṣe should be corrected to pelaikneṣṣai.
The verse interpunction is missing according to 70 fn. 7.

list.item: a1 ... the arrow piercing the heart ... avoid, you monks [56d?]. a2 || In Dharmasoma's Udānālaṅkāra the first part of the Satkāravarga. || In [the metre] Subhādra: || The jewel of the teaching, the Udāna, the monk's sign ["book of teaching"] [is] called the satiation of the good a3 Who dismisses all attachment, leaves all things behind him, severs all fetters, who has cleansed the mind of all things, he indeed can clearly understand the taste of monkhood. [1d] a4 The deed takes the possessions away from some, thieves rob them from others, too. The lord, the lover takes this away, the army will make that into odour, the fire burns it, [and] the water carries it [away]. a5 If one gives up possession and property by himself, by faith and world-weariness, he will not be able to gather a second time either. [2d] The householder must care for a lot of things, for slaves and female slaves, for [his] wife a6 for sons and daughters, for the service to the king, for the land’s levy, and for [his] own possession he must care, therefore they desire possession. But if he who has gone from the house and who is eating alms that he obtained by begging, [if he] is gathering possessions, a7 with great blemish he is besmirched. [3d] Had you cared for veneration and flattery, you should have stayed in the house yourselves [in the first place]. By your respective male and female slaves you certainly would have obtained veneration a8 [and] gathered possessions. Now you have gone from the house, by the wish for deliverance, [but] you let are bound [by] the fetters of veneration, flattery and profit. [4d] As if he was a miserable dog, [who is infected with] worms – [and] they eat by day b1 [and] night away at his wounds these worms – thus the worms of profit, when they are born into the wound of insatiability, eat [away] at his body of law by day [and] by night, he gets no [peace]. b2 With shining eyes he looks: wherefrom could I get possession? [5d] The discipline of monks he leads from house to house, he dismisses the study of the twelve kinds, he rejects meditation, he keeps away b3 knowledge; [only] veneration and flattery he desires. With the six ulterior motives he continually begs, street by street, house by house: this one and that one should flatter me. [6d] Only for me the kings should be, b4 only for me the ministers, only for me all [people] of this country. Householders and those having gone from the house should always make veneration only to me, not before anyone else should they bow to the ground. If he sees or hears b5 about the veneration of another, he burns in the fire of discord [thinking]: he should be standing there together with this one and that one. [7d] The Buddha spoke many Sūtras and about veneration and flattery countless words of cen- b6 -sure. This somehow I will show you here in brevity: [it is] a saying by the one having the ten powers: “You in whom arose an tendency for veneration and flattery, let [your] thoughts turn away [from it] as from this excrement b7 sewer.” [8d] “Just as the flood(?) here destroys the seeds, rips off the flowers [and] kills the fruits, so does veneration and flattery here destroy the seeds of moral conduct [and] also the flowers of enlightenment [and] the monk- b8 -hood's fruit (it kills).” “Of veneration and flattery ... [9d] ... (as) if it enters the forest, a (?)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Who lets go all clinging, gives up all things, cuts off all bonds, [his] mind turned away from all things, he can indeed clearly recognise the taste of monkhood. (cf [[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 54) 682
a4 The lord, [or] the beloved takes this, the army may reduce [lit. make] that to a scent, [or] fire burns it, [or] water carries it off. 705
a5 If someone himself gives up [his] property [and] possessions out of faith [and] weariness of the world, he will not gather [possessions] for a second time. (cf [[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 54–55) 682
a6-7 But if he who has left the house, eating begging [alms], gathers possessions, he is besmirched with great blame. (cf [[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 55) 682
a7-8 If you [pl.] had been concerned about reverence and flattery, [and] you [pl.] had yourselves further stayed in your [own] hous[es], then each of you would certainly have obtained reverence from his male and female slaves, [and] gathered possessions. ([[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 55, slightly different) 338
a8-b1 [Just] as when a miserable dog is wormy, [then] worms eat from his wounds by day and by night, so when the worms of profit are born in the wound of insatiability, they eat his dharma body by day and by night [and] he gets no rest. (cf [[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 55) 682
b4-5 If he sees or hears the honour of somebody else, he is burnt by the fire of jealousy: «this should be put together with that!» (cf [[TochSprR(B) I]]: ii, 55) 683

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Wer alle Haftungen löst, alle Dinge hinter sich lässt, alle Fesseln zerschneidet, [wer] den Geist von allen Dingen abgewendet(?) [hat], kann in der Tat den Geschmack des Mönchtums genau erkennen. 417
a4 Die Tat nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses [rest of translation missing in [[Schmidt 1974]].] 132-3, 409
a4 Das Karman nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie auch den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen. 497
a4 Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen. 263
a5 Wenn einer [von] selbst Besitz [und] Vermögen aufgibt im Glauben [und] Weltüberdruss, wird er [sie] auch nicht zum zweitenmal sammeln. 417
a6f. Wenn aber der, welcher aus dem Hause gegangen und Bettelbrot essend ist, Besitztümer sammelt, wird er mit großem Makel beworfen. 212, 401
a8 Ihr seid jetzt in dem Wunsche nach Erlösung aus dem Hause gegangen, [aber dennoch] lasst ihr euch (durch) die Bande des Verlangens nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei binden. 257
a8-b1 Wie wenn er ein elender Hund wäre, welcher Würmer hat - es fressen ihm bei Tag [und] Nacht die Würmer [an den] Wunden -, so fressen ihm die Würmer des Gewinns, wenn sie in der Wunde der Unersättlichkeit entstehen, [an] seinem Rechtskörper bei Tag [und] Nacht, er findet keine Ruhe. 194-5
b2-3 Die mönchische Zurückhaltung führt er Haus für Haus, gibt das Studium in den zwölf Arten auf, weist die Versenkung zurück, hält das Wissen fern; [nur] nach Ehre [und] Schmeichelei verlangt er. 154
b4 Haushalter [und] aus dem Hause Gegangene sollten nur mir stets Verehrung machen, nicht vor einem anderen sollten sie sich zur Erde neigen. 302-3
b4-5 Wenn er von der Verehrung eines anderen sieht oder hört, wird er vom Feuer der Eifersucht verzehrt [wtl. verbrannt] [in dem Gedanken]: ""Der müsste sich mit diesem und jenem zusammen hinstellen." 258, 293
b6-7 Ihr, denen hier die Neigung nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei entstanden [ist], lasset eure Gedanken sich [davon] abkehren wie von einer Kotgrube! 336

the dandas of a2 are missing in the transcription! Michael (Mon, 2014-10-06, 13:33:37)
Almost complete leaf, like [[THT 31]] damaged at the top edge.

a7 orocce|wrocce lupṣtär , nākimpa 3 #3d kwri yarke peti ; ṣeyme kurpelle ; ost olypo ṣaicer ; makci lamalyi : #4a ṣñār ṣñār mañyeṃ , mañyanameṃ ; nemcek yarke , källālyi ; a8 waipeccenta , kraupalyi : #4b latso ñake|ñk= ostameṃ ; kselñeṣṣe|kselñeṣṣ= akālksa : #4c yarke peti , källauṣṣana ; śänmānma , śanmästär 4 #4d mäkte yelyitstse|yelyitse ; ku tallāw tākaṃ ; śwāṃ-ne iṅkauṃ|yṅkau«ṃ» b1 kästuwer|kästwer ; yelyi pilenta : #5a mant källauṣṣi , yelyi cmentär ; ontsoytñeṣṣe , pīlene ; pelaikneṣṣ{ai} , kektseṃ cwi : #5b śwāṃ-ne iṅkauṃ|yṅkauṃ kästuwer|kästwer ; mā =ñu kälpāṣṣäṃ : #5c naumikkane b2 , lkāṣn eśnesa ; k_utameṃ källoym , waipecce 5 #5d saṃvar ṣamāññe ; āśäṃ ostw ostä ; tärknaṃ aklyilñe ; śakwi klautkeṃtsa : #6a ompalskoññe , päst praṅkäṣṣäṃ ; natknaṃ lauke , b3 aiśamñe ; yarke peti , ñaṣtär su|sū : #6b ṣkas toṃ tarstwasa ; ṣek su|sū yaskastär «:» #6c nauntai nauntai , ostä ostä ; se samp|sampä ksa , pautoy ñäś 6 #6d ñi kka ka tākoṃ ; lañc ṣe b4 meskepi ; ñi k= amācinta ; ñi ka po ypoyi : #7a ostä-ṣmeñcaṃ , ostmeṃ ltuweṣ ; ñi ka yarke , yāmyeṃ ṣek ; mā =lyekepi , keṃ ramoṃ : #7b lakaṃ klyauṣäṃ wat|wa|t b5 ; yark= alyekepi : #7c tsakṣtär ysalyṣe , pūwarsa su|sū ; ce compämpa , käccītär 7 #7d weña pūdñäkte|pudñäkte ; māka sutarma ; yarke petintse ; snai keś nakanma|naka|nma b6 : #8a tu ñiś tane , cek wärñai kca ; aultsorsa , ka ṣärpaume ; śkamaiyyantse , weweñor • #8b ket yarke petiś ; rmamñe tsäṅkau tne «:» #8c päklautkäṣṣat , päst pälskonta ; weṃṣyetsai b7 ramt , kotaimeṃ 8 #8d mäkte tne lāñe ; nakṣäṃ sarmana ; taṃtsäṣṣäṃ pya(py)aiṃ ; kauṣäṃ okonta : #9a mant tne yarke , peti nakṣäṃ ; śilaṣṣana , sarmana ; bodhyāṅkṣana , pyapyaiṃ no : #9b ṣamāññeṣṣana|ṣamā|(ññ)e(ṣṣana) b8 ; (k)au(ṣä)ṃ okonta : #9c yarke peti ·e /// /// warttone|(wa)r(t)one yopäṃ allāwo : ce –

yelyitse ku tallāw tākaṃ śwāṃ-ne yṅkau b1 _k_astwe_r\ yelyi pilenta : man_t\ _k_allauṣṣi yelyi cmen_t_a_r\ ontsoytñeṣṣe pīlene pelaikneṣṣe kektseṃ cwi : śwāṃ-ne yṅkauṃ _k_astwe_r\ mā =ñu _k_alpā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ : naumikkane b2 lkāṣn eśnesa k_utameṃ _k_alloy_mä\ waipecce 5 saṃva_r\ ṣamāññe ā_ś_aṃ ostw os_t_a _t_arknaṃ aklyilñe śakwi klautkeṃtsa : ompalskoññe _p_as_t\ praṅ_k_a_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ natknaṃ ñi ka po ypoyi : os_t_a-ṣmeñcaṃ ostmeṃ ltuwe_ṣ\ ñi ka yarke yāmyeṃ ṣe_k\ mā =lyekepi keṃ ramoṃ : lakaṃ klyau_ṣ_aṃ wa b5 _t\ yark= alyekepi : tsakṣ_t_a_r\ ysalyṣe pūwarsa sū ce com_p_ampa _k_accī_t_a_r\ 7 weña pudñäkte māka sutarma yarke petintse snai ke_ś\ naka b6 nma : tu ñi_ś\ tane cek wärñai kca [au]ltsorsa ka _ṣ_arpaume śkamaiyyantse weweño_r\ • ke_t\ yarke peti_ś\ rmamñe t_s_aṅkau tne _p_aklau_t_k_aṣṣa_t\ _p_as_t\ _p_alskonta weṃṣyetsai b7 ram_t\ kotaimeṃ 8 _m_akte tne lāñe na_k_ṣ_aṃ sarmana taṃt_s_a_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ [p]ya – [aiṃ] kau_ṣ_aṃ okonta [: ma]n_t\ tne yarke peti na_k_ṣ_aṃ śilaṣṣana sarmana bodhyāṅkṣana pyapyaiṃ no : ṣamā b8 ·e – – ·[au] ··[ṃ] okonta : yarke [p]e[t]i ·e /// /// r·o[n]e yo_p_aṃ allāwo : [c]e –
Book 13 (Satkāravarga), part 1, strophe 56(?), and part 2, strophes 1-9.

Transliteration

a5. The ‹pa› of kraupalle was added a posteriori to the manuscript according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 1.

Transcription

a3. According to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 69 fn. 8 the reading eṅkalñanta should be corrected to eṅkalñenta and according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 69 fn. 9 kerketse should be corrected to kerketseṃ in the transcription.
a5. According to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 1 mā ṣpä should be read as mā ṣp and according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 2 the reading māñye should be correctet to māñyeṃ.
a8. According to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 5 the reading yṅkau should be corrected to yṅkauṃ.
b1. According to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 6 the reading pelaikneṣṣe should be corrected to pelaikneṣṣai.
b6. The verse interpunction is missing according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 70 fn. 7.

General remarks

Includes remainders of the last strophe (56?) of the first part of the Satkāravarga (XIII) in a 21/21/18/13-syllable-metre and the beginning of the second part, strophes 1-9 in a 20/22/10/15-syllable-metre (rhythm: a: 5/5/5/5, b: 8/7/7, c: 5/5, d: 8/7).

div.p: the dandas of a2 are missing in the transcription! Michael (Mon, 2014-10-06, 13:33:37)
